Interactions with water as a shared resource
column7: Water is a critical resource for our operations and our communities. Our operations have site-specific water management plans reviewed and implemented continuously to ensure we responsibly manage water.

column13: Water is a critical resource for our operations and our communities. Our operations have site-specific water management plans reviewed and implemented continuously to ensure we responsibly manage water.

To manage rainfall and other inflows to the Bengalla water management system, our discharge dam provides 700ML of capacity. We hold credits to discharge water into the Hunter River during high flow and flood flow periods under the Hunter River Salinity Trading Scheme.
column20: Water management system, discharge dam, water trading scheme

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column7: We manage agricultural operations on rehabilitated land to support productive and enhanced land use. Our agricultural operations adjacent to both Bengalla and New Acland are used for cropping, cattle grazing, and dairy farming in the case of Bengalla.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: We also own and manage land for biodiversity to offset ecological disturbance at our mines under federal and state government requirements. Objectives of offsets for each specific area Ã¢ÂÂ including targeted flora and fauna species Ã¢ÂÂ are outlined in management plans approved by the relevant government bodies. Activities on these properties include managing weed and pest species, maintenance on fencing, controlled burns to manage bushfire risk and ecological surveys to monitor targeted flora and fauna.
column20: Biodiversity offsets, ecological disturbance, management plans

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: In Queensland at New Acland, we also manage several conservation zones in areas that have not been and will not be disturbed by mining. Like biodiversity offsets, these areas are managed under strict regulatory conditions. At our Lagoon Creek and Bottle Tree Hill conservation zones, we are working towards re-establishing native tree species.
column20: Conservation zones, re-establishing native species, rehabilitation

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: At New Acland, our rehabilitation program returns land to both agricultural and conservation uses, contributing to the region's agribusiness industry and re-establishing native species. Generally, the areas where mining occurred during New Acland Stages 1 and 2 are being returned to a combination of grazing land and enhanced rehabilitation bio-diverse areas.
column20: A Rehabilitation program, agricultural and conservation uses, the green movement

column7: GHG emissions, other than indirect (Scope 2) GHG emissions, occur as a consequence of an organisation's activities but are from sources that are not owned or controlled by the organisation. New Hope Group's Scope 3 emissions are dominated by coal consumption for power generation and other purposes at our customer sites.
Bengalla (100% basis) 0,1536 tCO2e/ROMt, New Acland 0,0353 tCO2e/ROMt, Jeebropilly 0,0460 tCO2e/ROMt, Bridgeport 0,1786 tCO2e/bbl, QBH 0,0035 tCO2e/tonnes throughput.

column8: National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting (NGER) Scheme
column13: New Hope reports on emissions, energy consumption and production to the Clean Energy Regulator annually through the National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting (NGER) Scheme. This includes recording and disclosing our Scope 1 and Scope 2 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions on an operational control basis.
column20: Greenhouse gas emissions reporting, NGER Scheme, Policy

column13: Reducing GHG emissions is a global challenge, with 195 countries formalising their commitment as signatories to the Paris Agreement. As part of its Nationally Determined Contribution under the Paris Agreement, the Australian Government has committed to a 43 per cent reduction in GHG emissions below 2005 levels by 2030 and net zero by 2050.

The NSW Government aims to achieve net zero emissions by 2050, and in 2023, the NSW Environmental Protection Agency foreshadowed the introduction of sector-based GHG emissions reduction targets, which may differ from the Australian Government targets. We will monitor developments to understand potential impacts on our operations.
column20: Net zero emissions, sector-based targets, NSW Government

column13: Our absolute emissions reduction trajectory will likely be 'lumpy' rather than linear, as specified under the Safeguard Mechanism. This reflects the time and investment required to plan and implement large-scale emissions reduction initiatives and that some emissions reduction will require shifts in entire industries that support coal mining. We will work within the Safeguard Mechanism framework to honour our obligations.
column20: Emissions reduction trajectory, Safeguard Mechanism, Policy

column13: Conducting a detailed emissions profiling activity to help focus our decarbonisation efforts.
Adopting an Enterprise Decarbonisation Framework sets out processes and accountabilities for GHG reduction initiatives across the Group.
column20: Enterprise Decarbonization Framework, GHG reduction, Strategy initiatives

column13: Developing a Group Carbon Model and incorporating a cost of carbon into our financial model.
column20: Group Carbon Model, cost of carbon, initiative

column13: We seek to implement incremental efficiencies that reduce our fuel emissions. At Bengalla, newly installed tailgates on an existing fleet of seven trucks have enabled higher coal payloads, reducing overall haulage requirements, while a new haulage corridor at the southern end of the mine will improve haulage efficiency.
column20: Incremental emissions reduction, fuel efficiency, energy

column13: New Acland's shallow fugitive emissions profile further limits feasible emissions capture projects. This year, we commissioned a conceptual study the potential for recovering fugitive emissions at Bengalla and will continue to assess the feasibility of such a project.
column20: Fugitive emissions capture, feasibility study, Strategy

column13: We are developing a carbon credit strategy for the Group as part of the suite of actions we expect will be necessary to meet Safeguard Mechanism obligations. The plan will incorporate purchasing ACCUs and consider opportunities to generate both ACCUs and SMCs on our existing land. Our carbon credit strategy will balance absolute emissions reduction efforts to ensure we meet our regulatory targets under the Safeguard Mechanism.
column20: Carbon credit Strategy, ACCUs, Safeguard Mechanism

column13: We assess investment decisions assuming that global net zero will be achieved by 2050 and have primary regard for Wood Mackenzie's Accelerated Energy Transition 1.5-Degree Scenario (AET1.5). This scenario assumes that despite population growth and rising GDP, by 2050, overall energy consumption will be materially lower than today due to rapid electrification and higher efficiency. This scenario also assumes that while fossil fuels' share of primary energy demand shrinks, low-carbon hydrogen and carbon capture use and storage play a central role in the energy system.
column20: Investment decisions, net zero emissions, AET1.5 scenario
